The author creates a loving and caring mood. In the second paragraph, the house is described as filled with the rich culinary creations of the parents, the passionate Cuban music in the air, and the enticing aromas from the kitchen in their warm home. The family has feasts and invites many immigrants into their house until they can stand on their own or find a place to live. The author believes that family isn't just about blood relations; everyone in the neighborhood is family, and they care for one another and those in need. At the end, the author says, “I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home.” They taught the author the true meaning of love and family, and the house is truly a warm and inviting place.

The author creates a mood of love, happiness, and the idea that family can be friends in the memoir. The author elaborates on how his mom and dad sacrificed everything for their child and his life. They had to change their entire lives after leaving Cuba, including their jobs. In Cuba, his dad worked in a laboratory and his mom studied chemical engineering, and they may have had to abandon these careers. This sacrifice and the love behind it contribute to the overall mood of love and happiness in the memoir, emphasizing the self - less nature of family.

The memoir exudes a mood of gratitude and contentment. The author conveys this sentiment through the quotes included. For instance, the statement “I was born into this simple house, situated in a two - family, blond - brick building in the ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey” indicates that the author was not overly concerned about the house's appearance, price, or location. Another quote, “It was here where I learned the real definition of family... [that it] had nothing to do with being a blood relative,” shows the author's gratitude towards those he now considers his “family.” The line “I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice... they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life” clearly expresses the author's gratefulness. Additionally, the author uses phrases in parentheses such as “(after which I eternally grateful)” and “(which I adore to this day)” to further emphasize his happiness and gratitude for his life. The quote “It was a close - knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need” also reveals that the “family” members were mutually grateful for one another. Overall, the memoir effectively portrays the author's grateful and content state of mind.

The author creates a mood of friendship and love in the memoir. When the author's parents moved to the United States, they established a traditional home, with the kitchen being the heart of it. As described, “Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen.” In the kitchen, celebrations, childhood memories, and gatherings of friends and family formed the backdrop of their lives. The author learned that “family” was not defined by blood relations. The neighborhood where the author lived consisted of diverse cultures that blended together to form a small community of honest, hard - working immigrants. These immigrants were always ready to help those in need. The author's parents “always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family.” Many of these immigrants left their lives in Cuba to move to the US, despite not knowing the language or culture, in order to provide a better life for their children. The author will always be thankful to her parents for their love and sacrifice, as they showed her the importance of family and friends when she was a child. The author states, “I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home.” They achieved this transformation through love and friendship, highlighting the significance of these values in creating a true home.

In the memoir, the author creates a loving and caring mood. Throughout the memoir, the speaker, Narciso Rodriguez, details what his family did after migrating from their native Cuba. His parents always kept an open - door policy, welcoming those they considered family, knowing that the favor would be returned. They cared deeply about their children's future and left behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. Although “they struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships,” they did what they believed was best for their children. Their simple house became the perfect place for the family to be together. As described, “The warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love.” This memoir made me realize the similarities between this family and mine. Without love, a family cannot truly exist, which is why at the end of the word “family,” the letters “i, l, y” can be seen as standing for “i love you.” In conclusion, the memoir effectively showcases the power of love and sacrifice within a family.

Reading this memoir gives me a warm and cozy feeling. When it discusses the concept of family not being limited to blood - related individuals, I immediately think of my friends and those I can rely on. They are also my family. The author also points out that a house is not necessarily a home without memories, family, and someone or something to trust. Finally, the author expresses his great gratitude for his parents bringing him to a neighborhood that he would grow to love. This piece has made me reflect on and appreciate my own family and home. It reminds me that the essence of a home lies in the relationships and memories we create within it.

The author creates a positive mood in the memoir. It describes the author's real - life situation. Family members would come to live with them until they got back on their feet, and having family around was a common occurrence. The author realized that they had transformed their “house into a Home.” Endless celebrations formed the backdrop of life in their warm home. Quotes like “they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in their country they loved” show the self - sacrifice of the immigrants. “The barriers to work were strong and high and my parents both accepted that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they had deserved.” In Cuba, Narciso, Sr. had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied Chemical Engineering. In the new place, they had to start their lives from scratch, taking any available work. The belief that this struggle would lead to better times for them and their children motivated them to endure the hardships. In my view, this is the mood that the author conveys in the memoir, highlighting the resilience and hope of the immigrant family.

In the memoir, the author crafts a mood imbued with love, care, and gratitude. Throughout, the author repeatedly expresses her deep - seated gratitude towards her parents and the profound love she holds for them. She states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This indicates her appreciation for her parents' selflessness in giving up their home, jobs, and friends to secure a better life for her. Additionally, she remarks that "what they [her parents] did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done." The author, Narciso, acknowledges the bravery required to venture into an unknown future, and she is extremely thankful that her parents took that step. These quotes clearly illustrate the loving, caring, and grateful mood expressed in the memoir.

It's quite challenging to precisely define the mood as the author presents a plethora of emotions. However, the most prominent feeling is unity and a sense of family. While family may not strictly be an emotion, it can be characterized by multiple emotions, one of which is unity, or as the author puts it, "great solidarity and friendship." It's rather endearing how the author views family as the bonds formed with people, in contrast to cultures where family is defined by blood ties and family always takes precedence. This perspective likely stems from the author's cultural background. There's also a touch of sadness, but overall, the author seems extremely thankful for what they have. As the saying goes, "happiness is nothing without appreciating it," and the author's statement "I learned the real definition of family" suggests that they have found true happiness.

The memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" evokes a mood of happiness, peace, and gratitude. Narciso is deeply appreciative of the sacrifices and lessons his parents bestowed upon him. His overall tone in the memoir translates into a happy and peaceful atmosphere. He writes, "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop of life to our warm home." This quote's calm and friendly tone depicts the happiness of his home life. By describing his house as "warm" with family and friend - centered celebrations, it creates the peaceful mood of the memoir. Narciso further adds to the peaceful mood by stating, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family," highlighting generosity and care towards family. The concept of family was the cornerstone of his loving childhood. The mood shifts to gratitude when Narciso thanks his parents for giving him a better life, despite their difficult jobs and circumstances. He expresses that he has "no way to express [his] gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon [him]," and "the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The values of family, love, and generosity Narciso learned from his parents underpin the gracious, happy, and tranquil mood of his memoir and his life.

The author establishes a tone of truthfulness, gratitude, and pride in the memoir. The quote "Passionate Cuban music... Filled the air mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. The author creates a very happy mood in the memoir. The atmosphere is filled with family, friends, joy, and happiness. Everyone is considered family, even during tough times. In Narciso's home, her young parents established a traditional home within the walls of their abode, with the kitchen at its heart. I believe the author has successfully set a mood of love from his family in the story. I firmly believe that the mood created by the author is one of gratefulness towards his parents. In the excerpt from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, @PERSON1 discusses the true meaning of "family", and a mood of gratitude is established. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," the author creates a grateful mood. Narciso expresses his thankfulness for his parents' support and love. When discussing his feelings towards his parents, he states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM1). The author creates a happy mood in the memoir. Narciso was content with all that his parents had done for him, and the neighborhood was peaceful, with everyone willing to help those in need. The memoir reflects on the author's childhood with a strong sense of nostalgia, creating a wistful mood. The memoir's overarching mood is one of gratitude. The author is deeply appreciative of their parents, who sacrificed their lives for the author's well - being. I believe the author crafted a memoir that evokes a complex blend of sadness and happiness. The emotions are so palpable that they truly draw the reader in. The author effectively creates two distinct moods in the excerpt: @CAPS1 and love. Initially, the mood is @CAPS1. In paragraph @NUM1, it states, "They struggled both personally and financially." In this memoir, the mood is shaped by Narciso and his family. @PERSON2's family contributes to the mood by bringing the family together in their old home in Cuba and their new one in @LOCATION1. @PERSON2 further enhances the mood through their love for the family and by consistently expressing gratitude for all the family has done, from the author's childhood to adulthood. Moreover, @PERSON2's family shows great kindness by taking in those with nowhere to go and supporting them until they can stand on their own. The mood crafted by the author in the memoir is complex and difficult to define precisely. It is often confusing as there are multiple emotions presented. The author establishes a @CAPS1 yet happy atmosphere in the @CAPS2, which is about a boy whose parents immigrated. The mood established by the author in the memoir is one of happiness. Throughout most paragraphs, the author, Narciso, expresses his deep love for his parents and Cuban culture. He details how his parents transformed their ordinary house into a home. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, a distinct mood is palpable. I am of the opinion that the intended mood is one of joy and upliftment. Narciso held deep gratitude towards his parents. Their family life encompassed love, happiness, and moments of depression, perhaps more. The author's memoir was both sorrowful and filled with love. He adored how they transformed the simple dwelling into a place rich with Cuban traditions. Moreover, he appreciated their way of creating a warm and inviting home environment. His parents had shown great courage in coming to this country. Like many immigrants, they selflessly came to provide a better life for their children. Narciso was so thankful that he expressed his gratitude to his parents daily for the love they had created. It was in this simple house that his parents celebrated his first birthday. He preserved the house as a memoir, a constant reminder of his journey to America. The house was a place that exuded love, care, and cheerfulness.

In the memoir penned by fashion designer Narciso Rodriguez, his writing about his childhood home conveys a distinct tone. The mood in the memoir is variable, but predominantly sad. It depicts how Narciso's parents selflessly sacrificed what they had for their children's well - being. In 1956, the father in the Cuban family came to [place] for a better future for his family. They had an apartment with two rooms. The family had two sons. One son was twenty - one and the other was twenty - seven. This move was a significant step for the family in their pursuit of a better life.

In this memoir, the author, Narciso Rodriguez, effectively establishes a mood that resonates deeply. For me, it was so immersive that I was completely drawn into the narrative. I believe Rodriguez crafted a “home sweet home” atmosphere. This is evident when he states, “within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen.” This description brought to mind my own family and our shared love for cooking Puerto Rican food. The aroma is akin to a warm welcome home. In my household, everyone is embraced, regardless of blood relation, and Rodriguez also touches on this sense of inclusivity in his memoir. Moreover, he expresses profound gratitude as his parents immigrated to pursue a better life. This gratitude contributes to the loving and family - centered mood of the memoir. As Rodriguez puts it, “I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home.” Even after their immigration, Rodriguez will always cherish his childhood home. Clearly, this memoir is rich with diverse moods.

In the memoir “Narciso Rodriguez,” a complex mood of happiness, sadness, and gratitude pervades. Narciso experiences happiness as he often gets to spend quality time with his family. He is also looking forward to more family members arriving from Cuba in the coming years. However, he is saddened by the fact that he cannot see his grandfather and that his parents did not have as privileged a life as he does. His gratitude is palpable; he is thankful for being alive and for his parents’ selfless efforts in bringing him to the United States. Their actions allowed him to live a wonderful life. Overall, these emotions combine to create the distinct mood of the memoir.

The memoir penned by Narciso Rodriguez is imbued with an appreciative and thankful tone. His mood exuded pure happiness. The source of this happiness was being in the company of his family. It involved sharing moments, gathering together, and having wonderful times with family members. He believed in not changing for anyone and taking risks, even if it meant moving to a different state. The key was to share freely with family, always be there for each other, and express oneself authentically. This kind of family - centered and adventurous approach to life was the foundation of his happiness.

The mood created by the @CAPS1 in the memoir has some flaws. Initially, it struggles to fully develop the character. The pacing is inconsistent; it goes slow, then fast, and then slow again. In 1961, Narciso was born into a traditional Cuban home. The kitchen was the heart of this home, filled with the love of his parents, who were passionate about cooking and are still with him today, for which he is eternally grateful. Selflessly, like many immigrants, they left behind their families, friends, and careers in their beloved homeland to give their children a better life. They endured personal and financial struggles, braved the harsh Northern winters while longing for their native tropics and faced cultural hardships. In the memoir, the author successfully cultivates a mood of happiness and gratitude. The innocence of childhood, the gatherings of family and friends, and the continuous celebrations that involved both formed the backdrop of life in our warm home. In our neighborhood, despite the customs in other places, all these cultures united in great solidarity and friendship. I will forever be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez: From Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", the text conveys a range of emotions including happiness, gratitude, and sadness. Firstly, there is a mood of happiness. The author of the memoir creates a warm, happy, and pleasant mood. When Narciso Rodriguez describes his home in Newark, @CAPS1, it gives a strong sense of the joy of his Cuban home. The author of the memoir conveys a mood of thankfulness and happiness. He is deeply grateful for his parents, who gave up their entire lives in Cuba to move to America for the sake of their children. In the immigrant section of Newark, New Jersey, within the walls of their home, my young parents established our traditional Cuban household. The heart of this home was the kitchen. Both of my parents took on cooking responsibilities and, without realizing it, passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love for cooking that has endured. This home and the cooking traditions within it have become an important part of my life, shaping my connection to my Cuban heritage.

In Narciso Rodriguez's passage, a loving and grateful mood is established. In Cuban culture, every family has a tradition that they pass down to their children. Every father tells or gives something, which could be a knife or a gold chain. This uncertainty about the family - passed traditions reflects the significance and mystery that such legacies hold in our lives.

Most importantly, his parents taught him two crucial lessons: the spirit of generosity and the significance of family and friends. The author describes a warm and happy mood in the memoir. The author @ORGANIZATION1 emphasizes the importance of family, which always evokes a comforting feeling. The memoir of Narciso Rodriguez is imbued with a mood of gratitude. Narciso's parents migrated from Cuba to @LOCATION2 to offer their children a more prosperous life than they had experienced. Initially, they resided in a one - room house until they moved to New Jersey, where Narciso was raised. Within that dwelling, the family established a vibrant Cuban community. The heart of the home was the kitchen, where Cuban music played continuously. The area of New Jersey where the Rodriguez family lived was populated by Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. The community resembled a large family, with cultures uniting in great solidarity and friendship. These cultural interactions taught Narciso the true meaning of "family." If his parents had not been selfless and made the arduous journey to start anew, he would not have had these experiences. As Narciso states, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This shows the deep - seated gratitude he feels for his parents' sacrifices.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," the author creates a mood centered around love.
